protocols.name: Chest Pain / Cardiac Event
steps: Call emergency services immediately (999 or 1199)
Have the person sit down and rest in a comfortable position
Loosen any tight clothing around the neck and chest
If aspirin is available and the person is not allergic, give 300mg to chew
Monitor breathing and consciousness
Be prepared to perform CPR if person becomes unresponsive

protocols.name: Severe Bleeding / Hemorrhage
steps: Call emergency services immediately
Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage
Maintain pressure continuously for at least 10 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level if possible
Do not remove the cloth even if it becomes soaked - add more layers
Keep the person warm and calm
Monitor for signs of shock

protocols.name: Unconsciousness / Unresponsive
steps: Call emergency services immediately
Check for breathing - look, listen, and feel for 10 seconds
If breathing normally, place in recovery position (on their side)
If not breathing, begin CPR immediately
Clear the airway of any obstructions
Monitor breathing and pulse continuously
Do not give anything by mouth

protocols.name: Difficulty Breathing / Respiratory Distress
steps: Call emergency services immediately
Help the person sit upright or in a comfortable position
Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
If person has an inhaler, help them use it
Reassure the person and encourage slow, deep breaths
Open windows for fresh air
Monitor breathing rate and consciousness

protocols.name: Burns
steps: Remove person from heat source safely
Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for 20 minutes
Remove jewelry and tight clothing before swelling occurs
Cover burn with clean, non-stick bandage or cloth
Do not apply ice, butter, or ointments
If burn is severe or covers large area, call emergency services
Monitor for signs of shock

protocols.name: Fracture / Broken Bone
steps: Do not move the injured area
Immobilize the fracture with a splint if available
Apply ice packs wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling
Elevate the injured limb if possible
Monitor circulation beyond the injury (check pulse, color, warmth)
Call emergency services for severe fractures or if unable to move safely
Do not try to realign the bone

protocols.name: Head Injury / Trauma
steps: Call emergency services for severe head injuries
Keep the person still and lying down
Apply firm pressure to bleeding areas with clean cloth
Monitor level of consciousness - keep person awake and talking
Watch for signs of concussion: confusion, vomiting, unequal pupils
Do not move person if spinal injury is suspected
Do not give any medications without medical advice

protocols.name: Seizure / Convulsion
steps: Stay calm and time the seizure
Clear the area of hard or sharp objects
Place something soft under the person's head
Turn person on their side to help with breathing
Do not restrain movements or put anything in the mouth
Call emergency services if seizure lasts more than 5 minutes
Stay with person until fully conscious

protocols.name: Severe Allergic Reaction / Anaphylaxis
steps: Call emergency services immediately
If person has an EpiPen, help them use it immediately
Have person lie down and elevate legs
Loosen tight clothing
Monitor breathing and pulse
Be prepared to perform CPR
Do not give anything by mouth if person is having trouble breathing

protocols.name: Stroke
steps: Call emergency services immediately - use FAST test:
F - Face: Ask person to smile, check for drooping
A - Arms: Ask person to raise both arms, check for weakness
S - Speech: Ask person to repeat a simple phrase, check for slurred speech
T - Time: Note the time symptoms started
Keep person calm and comfortable
Do not give anything to eat or drink

protocols.name: Poisoning / Toxic Ingestion
steps: Call poison control center or emergency services immediately
Identify the substance if possible
Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by medical professionals
If unconscious, place in recovery position
Keep sample of substance or container
Monitor breathing and consciousness
Follow specific instructions from poison control

protocols.name: High Fever
steps: Take temperature regularly
Give appropriate fever-reducing medication (paracetamol or ibuprofen)
Remove excess clothing and blankets
Keep room temperature comfortable
Encourage drinking plenty of fluids
Use cool compresses on forehead if needed
Seek medical attention if fever exceeds 39°C (102°F) or persists

protocols.name: Sprain / Strain
steps: Rest the injured area
Ice: Apply ice pack for 20 minutes every 2-3 hours
Compression: Wrap with elastic bandage (not too tight)
Elevation: Keep injured area raised above heart level
Take over-the-counter pain medication if needed
Avoid using the injured area for 24-48 hours
Seek medical attention if severe pain or unable to bear weight
